title: Quiz 5: Protection, Support & Movement
description: Assessment covering The Skin (Ch 14), Resistance and Immunity (Ch 15), and The Musculoskeletal System (Ch 16). Focuses on integumentary functions, immune responses, bone structure, and muscle physiology.

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the skin and underlying tissue from superficial (outside) to deep (inside).
questions.explanation: The Epidermis is on top (cornified layer then basal layer), followed by the Dermis (connective tissue), then the Subcutaneous fat layer, resting on muscle/bone.
questions.hint: Epi- means 'upon' or 'above'.

questions.question: Match the bone cell type with its function:

pairs.right: Mature bone cells that maintain tissue

questions.explanation: OsteoBlasts Build bone. OsteoClasts Crash/Consume bone. Osteocytes maintain it.
questions.hint: B for Build, C for Crash/Consume.

questions.question: A nurse receives a needle-stick injury and is given an injection of ready-made antibodies (immunoglobulins) against Hepatitis B. What type of immunity does this represent?

richContent.content:
Scenario Analysis:
The body did NOT make the antibodies itself (Passive).
The antibodies were introduced medically/artificially (Artificial).

questions.explanation: It is 'Passive' because the body isn't making the antibodies. It is 'Artificial' because it was injected (not from mother to baby).
questions.hint: Is the body doing the work? Is it a medical intervention?

questions.question: Which of the following are cardinal signs of acute inflammation? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The signs of inflammation are Redness, Heat, Swelling, Pain, and Loss of Function. Pallor is associated with shock/poor perfusion.
questions.hint: Think about what happens to your skin when a bee stings it.

questions.question: What is the name of the pigment secreted by melanocytes that protects the skin from UV radiation and determines skin colour?
questions.explanation: Melanin absorbs UV light to protect DNA in skin cells.
questions.hint: Starts with 'M'.

questions.question: Using the 'Rule of Nines' for burns in adults, what percentage of the body surface area is affected if BOTH entire legs are burned?

richContent.content:
Reference:
Head = 9%
Each Arm = 9%
Front Torso = 18%
Back Torso = 18%
Each Leg = 18%
Genitals = 1%

questions.explanation: Each entire leg counts as 18%. Two legs = 18% + 18% = 36%.
questions.hint: 18 plus 18.

questions.question: Match the type of joint with its description:

pairs.right: Allows movement in all planes (e.g., Hip)

questions.explanation: Fibrous=Fixed. Cartilaginous=Cushioned/Slight movement. Synovial=Free movement.
questions.hint: Which one allows you to wave your arm?

questions.question: The epidermis contains blood vessels.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The epidermis is avascular (no blood vessels). Nutrients must diffuse up from the dermis below.
questions.hint: If you scratch your skin lightly and it doesn't bleed, have you reached blood vessels?

questions.question: The functional contractile unit of a skeletal muscle fiber is called the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Sarcomeres contain the actin and myosin filaments arranged in units.
questions.hint: Starts with 'S'. Contains actin and myosin.

questions.question: Which antibody (immunoglobulin) is the most abundant in the blood and is the only one capable of crossing the placenta?
questions.explanation: IgG is the most common (General) and crosses the placenta to protect the fetus (Gestational).
questions.hint: Think G for General or Gestation.

questions.question: Order the stages of bone healing following a fracture.
questions.explanation: Blood clot (hematoma) -> Soft tissue/cartilage (procallus) -> Hard bone (callus) -> Reshaping (remodeling).
questions.hint: Bleeding happens first.

questions.question: Which of the following are part of the AXIAL skeleton? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Axial skeleton is the central axis (Skull, Spine, Ribs). The Appendicular skeleton includes limbs and girdles (Arms, Legs, Pelvis, Scapula).
questions.hint: The central core of the body.

questions.question: What distinguishes 'Secondary Healing' (Second Intention) from 'Primary Healing' of a wound?

options.text: Secondary healing occurs when edges are brought together (sutured)
Secondary healing involves minimal tissue loss and little scarring
Secondary healing occurs in open wounds with extensive tissue loss, healing from the bottom up
Secondary healing happens faster than primary healing

questions.explanation: Secondary healing happens in gaping wounds (like ulcers) where edges cannot be approximated. Granulation tissue must fill the gap, causing more scarring.
questions.hint: Think of a wide gap vs a clean surgical cut.

questions.question: Match the type of hypersensitivity with its example:
questions.explanation: Type I=Immediate/Allergy. Type II=AntiBody/Blood. Type III=Complexes. Type IV=Delayed/T-cell.
questions.hint: Type I is the most common allergy type.

questions.question: Review the comparison table. Which form of arthritis is described in Column B?

richContent.content:
FeatureColumn AColumn B
CauseDegenerative (Wear & tear)Autoimmune
JointsWeight-bearing (Knees/Hips)Small joints (Hands/Feet)
OnsetLate middle ageAny age (often 30-50)

questions.explanation: Column B describes Rheumatoid Arthritis (Autoimmune, small joints). Column A is Osteoarthritis.
questions.hint: It's an autoimmune disease.

questions.question: The neurotransmitter released at the neuromuscular junction to stimulate skeletal muscle contraction is ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Acetylcholine (ACh) crosses the synaptic cleft to bind to receptors on the muscle fiber.
questions.hint: Often abbreviated ACh.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the skin? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Skin protects, regulates temp, senses environment, and makes Vitamin D. Blood cells are made in bone marrow, not skin.
questions.hint: It does almost everything except make blood.

questions.question: Order the sequence of events in skeletal muscle contraction.

items.text: Calcium is released from sarcoplasmic reticulum
Actin and Myosin filaments slide over each other

questions.explanation: Nerve signal -> ACh -> Calcium release -> Sliding filaments -> Contraction.
questions.hint: Nerves signal before chemistry happens, which happens before movement.

questions.question: Which term describes the movement of a limb AWAY from the midline of the body?
questions.explanation: Abduction moves away (like abducting/taking away). Adduction adds to the midline.
questions.hint: Think of an alien taking someone away.

questions.question: What is the term for a substance that the body recognizes as foreign and that triggers an immune response?
questions.explanation: An antigen (Antibody Generator) triggers the immune response.
questions.hint: Starts with 'A'.

questions.question: Match the skin gland with its secretion:
questions.explanation: Sebaceous=Oil. Eccrine=Cooling sweat. Apocrine=Scent sweat. Ceruminous=Wax.
questions.hint: Sebum is oil.

questions.question: Which condition is characterized by a reduction in bone density, making bones fragile and prone to fracture, particularly in post-menopausal women?
questions.explanation: Osteoporosis (porous bone) is the loss of bone mass. Osteoarthritis is joint degeneration. Osteomyelitis is bone infection.
questions.hint: Porous bones.

questions.question: Innate (non-specific) immunity produces a specific memory of the pathogen for faster response upon re-exposure.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Innate immunity is non-specific and has NO memory. Adaptive (Specific) immunity creates memory cells.
questions.hint: Does your skin remember specific bacteria?

questions.question: Which of the following changes occur in the skin due to ageing? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Thinning of the epidermis and dermis

questions.explanation: Ageing causes thinning, loss of elasticity, dryness (reduced sweat/sebum), and less Vit D. Subcutaneous fat usually decreases, leading to sagging.
questions.hint: Think about the skin of an elderly person: is it thick and oily or thin and dry?

questions.question: The process where a white blood cell engulfs and digests a bacterium is called ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Phagocytosis is 'cell eating'.
questions.hint: Starts with 'P'.

questions.question: What is the main function of 'Helper T-cells' (CD4 cells)?

options.text: To coordinate the immune response and stimulate other cells

questions.explanation: Helper T-cells are the 'generals' of the immune system; they activate B-cells and Cytotoxic T-cells. HIV destroys them.
questions.hint: They 'help' everyone else work.

questions.question: Match the bone with its shape classification:
questions.explanation: Femur=Long. Carpals=Short. Sternum=Flat. Vertebrae=Irregular.
questions.hint: Think about the shape of the breastbone vs the thigh bone.

questions.question: What is the term for a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction characterised by bronchoconstriction and hypotension?
questions.explanation: Anaphylaxis is a systemic Type I hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.hint: Starts with 'A'.

questions.question: Which mineral is stored in bone and is essential for muscle contraction?
questions.explanation: Calcium is stored in the bone matrix and is released for muscle and nerve function.
questions.hint: Milk is rich in it.

questions.question: Arrange the sections of the vertebral column from superior (top) to inferior (bottom).
questions.explanation: Neck (Cervical) -> Chest (Thoracic) -> Lower Back (Lumbar) -> Pelvis (Sacrum/Coccyx).
questions.hint: C-T-L-S-C.
